title: SOFTS-Raw sugar unchanged but posts 2nd straight weekly gain
text:
© Reuters. SOFTS-Raw sugar unchanged but posts 2nd straight weekly gain

(Adds comment, background; adds NEW YORK to dateline)

NEW YORK/LONDON, Sept 27 (Reuters) - Raw sugar futures were unchanged on Friday but posted a second successive weekly gain, boosted by an expected tightening in supplies in the coming months.

Cocoa moved lower, while coffee traded up slightly.

SUGAR

* March raw sugar SBc2 was unchanged at 12.62 cents per lb. The contract rose to a peak of 12.72 cents on Thursday, the highest for the benchmark second position since Aug. 16.

* The March contract gained 4.6% in the week.

* Dealers said the expiry of the October contract on Monday was providing a short-term focus, with a sharp decline in the open interest during the past few days leading most to expect the amount of sugar delivered will be modest.

* The latest open-interest data, as of Sept. 26, showed a daily decline of more than 50% to 18,466 lots, equating to 923,300 tonnes of sugar.

* The market remains underpinned by the prospect of a global deficit for the 2019/20 season, though any significant rise in prices could spark large exports from India.

* "Analysts' consensus is that India will export 3-4 million tonnes in season 2019. That view though is price-dependent. At the right price, India probably still has capacity to export more," Commonwealth Bank of Australia analyst Tobin Gorey wrote in a market note.

* December white sugar settled up $1.6, or 0.5%, at $341.4 per tonne, just below a six-month high of $342 set on Thursday. The contract was up 4.8% in the week.

COCOA

* December New York cocoa CCZ9 settled down $15, or 0.6%, at $2,490 per tonne. The contract rose 0.7% in the week

* Dealers said short-covering by speculators helped fuel the recent run-up. CFTC data on Friday showed a third consecutive decline in speculators' bearish positions. CFTC/

* The 2019/20 Ivory Coast main crop season starts on Tuesday, with farmgate prices expected to rise to 825 CFA francs from 750 francs.

* Cocoa buyers have been storing large quantities of cocoa beans in the bush for the past six weeks as they wait for a higher farmgate price, raising fears over bean quality, exporters and buyers said on Thursday. March LCCc2 settled down 5 pounds, or 0.3%, at 1,880 pounds per tonne. The contract was up 1.8% on the week.

COFFEE

* December arabica coffee KCZ9 settled up 0.05 cent, or 0.1%, at $1.009 per lb.

* November robusta coffee settled up $7, or 0.5%, at $1,321 per tonne.
description: SOFTS-Raw sugar unchanged but posts 2nd straight weekly gain
